headline: Pat's Baked Beans
description: Not your average baked beans! This recipe combines pinto, northern, baked, kidney and garbanzo beans with bacon and onion. Try this for a break from the ordinary.
name: Pat's Baked Beans
recipeIngredient: 1 (16 ounce) can great Northern beans, drained
1 (16 ounce) can red kidney beans, drained

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).

Place bacon in a large, deep skillet. Cook over medium high heat until evenly brown. Drain, reserving 2 tablespoons of drippings, crumble and set aside in a large bowl. Cook the onion and garlic in the reserved drippings until onion is tender; drain excess grease and transfer to the bowl with the bacon.

To the bacon and onions add pinto beans, northern beans, baked beans, kidney beans and garbanzo beans. Stir in ketchup, molasses, brown sugar, Worcestershire sauce, mustard and black pepper. Mix well and transfer to a 9x12 inch casserole dish.
Cover and bake in preheated oven for 1 hour.

review.reviewBody: This recipe is so much as my recipe for baked beans. I use navy beans.
5 stars HOWEVER, I used 2 cans pinto beans & 2 of northern. We use kidneys for chili and are not garbanzo bean fans. It turned out great!
Good and you can add whichever beans you want.
really easy recipe. tasted great.

I'm not sure how I've never rated this before. I have this saved and I make this regularly for BBQs and other events. I'm making it again today. I pretty much have it down (I do put my own spin on it). I just wanted to make sure I wasn't missing something this time! Thanks Pat!
A staple for every big BBQ
Too sweet, lower the brown sugar
It was very good except for the garbanzo beans would not soften up. Leave those out if you don’t want a slight crunchy bean in your baked beans.

I made these in a crock pot on low for 6-8 hours. Also decreased the molasses and increased the brown sugar. Added butter beans, a tablespoon of liquid smoke flavoring and 3 tablespoons of vinegar. Delish!

These will be my go to baked beans. This is my 2nd time making them. First time, they were too runny, totally my fault. This time, they turned out perfect. I added 1.5 jalapeños, for fun and because I had them chopped up in the refrigerator. 
I did them in the pressure cooker. I’ll move them to a casserole dish, then freeze them till my potluck later this week. I’ll get them hot again and take them to the potluck.
This has become a favorite at family gatherings! Thank you for the recipe.

made it exactly as the recipe says the first time in the oven i felt the beans needed to cook longer after 4 hours. the second time I made it and let.it sit overnight in the fridge and put it in a slow cooker on low for 8 hours and it was amazing. even the kid who hates everything liked them
I've made this recipe a few times. The only thing I would change, is eliminate one can of beans.
I made this for my family get together. They must have loved them because the pan was empty after dinner.
Not worth the time spent- won’t make again

I made this first as written and it was good. I adjusted to our taste, and now it's always a hit when I bring it to parties. Here are my adjustments:
Sub either pinto or great northern beans for the garbanzo beans. 
No brown sugar (there's plenty of sugar in the ketchup to thicken up)
2 T of molasses
Add a splash of tobasco
Didn't use bacon, just the beans and the other ingredients. It came out great and sweet. Will definitely make again, and again.
These beans are very good. I wonder if for half the recipe, it would be enough to cook it on the range top.... It's a perfect potluck recipe!

This recipe is excellent as written. I have made it 3-4 times as written. The last three times that I have made this I have added the following items to the recipe: One can each of White and Yellow Corn, Red Pepper Flakes, Cayenne Pepper, Hot Sauce and a total of 1 LB of Bacon. The Corn adds sweetness and more servings. Just my twist.. ..outstanding recipe and I Thank You!

I decided to leave all the bacon grease in, and used 2 cloves of garlic instead of 1 clove.
In spite of that, it just tasted like a big batch of 'Bushs Baked Beans'.
Next time I want a flavor like this, I'll just buy Bush's.
Took this dish to a block party and it was a hit! None left at the end of the party!
Love, love, love! I usually just throw everything in a crockpot and cook on high for about 6hrs. Great for summer bbq's and potlucks.
I followed the recipe except for substituting black beans for one of the others...everyone loved them. I will definitely make this again

this is always a hit. I brown ground beef and add that to make it more a meal. I add green peppers which adds to the flavor of the beans. I spoon out about a quart of the juice and put it into a pot and thicken it with corn starch and put it back in the pot.
My go to recipe. Always get requests to share the recipe!
Very good recipe! I didn’t change any of the ingredients listed, just added some diced jalapeños for a little kick. Everyone loved them!

Very good!!! 
I chose this recipe because it had the least amount of sugar and molasses. It was so tasty. Made it for Independence Day and it went perfectly with bbq'd hamburgers and watermelon.

I've made this a few times now. The first couple of times it went over really well. I love the combination of beans--original for baked beans. 
 Thank you! The last couple times I made it, it was not as well received. Next time I'll double the beans or cut the sauce ingredients in half; as written it's just too strong for us, all intense sauce & no bean flavor.
Yum!!! I doubled the recipe (approximately). The dish was a huge 4th of July hit.
They were good - but nothing exceptional. I won't make this again.
They were terrible. I think it was the molasses that ruined them. Next time, I’ll heat up a can of Bush’s.

I made this for a Father’s Day bbq and it was a huge hit! I kept It in a glass casserole dish with foil over it, so it wouldn’t dry up (we had at least a hour before all the food was ready) when we set the tablet the beans were still hot and not in the least dried out. They were so good. I’ll be making them again for some more summer bbq’s and maybe next time in a crockpot
I didn't make any changes. Terrific!

A new family favorite! I followed the suggestions of a few other reviewers - swapped out the garbanzo beans for Great Northern, reduced the molasses and the brown sugar - to accommodate my family's tastes. Kept all the seasonings. I drained all the beans except for two cans, which came in flavored sauces. Make it with the beans you like! This wasn't too soupy as some baked bean dishes are. No running all over the plate! Absolutely delicious, and the various bean textures and colors make the dish attractive and interesting. It's nice to have a good baked bean recipe that doesn't require soaking beans.

I don’t like ketchup or mustard so I used barbecue sauce instead & made them in a crockpot on low for 3 hours, then turned it up to high for an hour or two. I also used turkey bacon & used spicy chili beans to replace the canned baked beans. I was really nervous because I was making this for a group that was camping with us, but everyone LOVED them!!! I’ve already been told I have to make them next time.
There are many reviews for this, and I have nothing to add except one more 5-star review. I easily halved it. Yummy!
Fantastic flavor. I subbed butter beans for the garbanzo otherwise made just as listed.
Awesome baked beans recipe - perfect for brisket, ribs or any or barbecue and smoked food...
Awesome baked beans! I will definitely make this again and again!
Oh. My. Gosh. This is amazing!! So versatile, make it sweet, make it tangy or spicy!! YUMMO!

I've made these over and over and always get rave reviews. Now that I'm cooking for less people I trim down the ingredients and still delicious! My husband is now a pre-diabwtic so I've started making them with one Tbls Stevia brown sugar, leave off the molasses and still got rave reviews!
So I made mine in crockpot ...kidney beans, baked beans and great northern beans plus diced peppers and onions. Made the sauce mix all together and LOVE IT!

What I love about baked beans is the deep, bacony flavor and the mushy beans. Unfortunately, this recipe was not a favorite. Because so many different types of beans are used, some are mushy and some are hard (the garbanzo and kidney beans). My husband even asked if it was finished cooking after the hour and 15 minutes I put it in for. Also, I don't think there is a super deep flavor. I would recommend putting this in a crock pot for several hours instead of baking for an hour.
My Mom, has been making this recipe for so many years, we call them Pam’s beans now. Best baked beans in the world!
Excellent. Tweeked it a little by adding green pepper and lowering the amount of molasses and brown sugar by a 1/4 of each.
Outstanding. Added a bit more bacon other than that did the recipe as written
OUTSTANDING..... 1/2 the Mollasses, 1 pound of Bacon.. Dijon Mustard, tsp of Pepper, GARBANZOS ALWAYS !!! THEY RULE !!

Made this for a beach week dinner side dish and it was a huge hit! Used black beans instead of garbanzos. Left out the garlic at the request of my sister but I bet it would have been great if I had included. Will definitely make again.

I’d give 5 stars but it needed a little heat and WAAAAYYYYY more bacon. Thanks for the recipe! I served it at our neighborhood bbq. It was a hit. I made two versions. One as recipe says the other with my mods: TBS hot sauce, TBS crushed red pepper, pound of bacon, 2 med\lg sweet onions. I’m adding a pic of before baking. It’s definitely a little runny. Maybe because of the extra onions but people loved it soupy.

I made this exactly as written and it was great! Next time I may cook them a bit longer or slow cook them in he crock pot to soften the beans a bit more, but the flavor was perfect. I will be making these for my son’s football team next week...and tripling the recipe!

These were absolutely fantastic and so easy to make! I forgot to get a can of pinto beans while at the store but I had a 28oz can of Bush's baked beans so I threw the whole can in. It tasted amazing with the perfect blend of sweet and tangy. I took it to a Labor Day party and everyone though they were great! Definitely a keeper. I did follow another persons suggestion and took the foil off and kept in oven for another 15 mins or so to thicken it up and make sure all the beans were cooked. I suggest that as it helped get the consistency just right.
I used a crockpot on high for 4 hours, took the lid off for 1/2 hour to increase thickness. These are THE.BEST.BAKED.BEANS (made in a crockpot ??). Thanks Kelly!

Delicious, if you are not from the USA and don't like food too sweet I suggest using less molasses. It is better to use a mixture of beans but it seems to work with any combination. I definitely recommend this recipe and will be taking it to our next family gathering.

As others have said, this is a recipe from the better homes and gardens cookbook. Mine is in storage and I was so happy to find it online when I needed my “famous” beans recipe! Make this! You won’t regret it. I’ve been making it for years. I cook the bacon and onions in a Dutch oven, then mix all the ingredients in and pop it in the oven - less dishes! Tonight I threw in some leftover shredded rib meat and served with cornbread. Yum!

I personally do not care for baked beans so I didn’t eat any of the beans but I got rave reviews from all of my family. My husband said that these were the best baked beans he has ever eaten!! I made this exactly like the recipe and I wouldn’t change a thing! Thanks for an awesome recipe!!
I tweaked it up a bit with some smoked paprika and maple syrup, delicious. Much easier than starting from scratch and soaking beans overnight.
Actually, I added 1/2 lb of minced ham and left the bacon out.
Best beans ever. Substituted an extra can of kidney beans instead of garbanzo beans. Otherwise, followed the receipt just as it is.

I made a recipe like this a few year ago and am still getting requests for it at pot luck dinners. Found this one and it was close enough to the original (might have been the same one).
I use more bacon (half pound), a dash of cayenne and a quarter cup of dark rum. This one is a good recipe on its own or start before adding your own special ingredients. I cook it in a cast iron chicken fryer (a skillet with higher sides) and server it right from the skillet.
Great recipe. Easy to prepare. Substituted black beans for the pinto beans and simmered in a slow cooker for a few hours on low. Delicious!

I made these for a big family BBQ and they were a huge hit. I doubled the recipe and let them cook in the crock pot all day. Didn't change anything else in the recipe. Loved these and will definitely make again.

WOW! These beans were a grand slam! Initially I wasn't sure that I'd want to use the garbanzos again (believe me, I most certainly will be making this dish again!!!), but the next day, after everything had a chance to sit and get happy together, the flavors and textures were perfect. Thanks for the recipe.
I used 2 cans of kidney beans and 2 cans of black and it was a huge hit!
I've made this numerous times! It never fails to please. I've added black beans to it before. They add to the variation in color.
we love this recipe. Like everything else, my husband has added his won flair, but the base recipe here is amazing.

I didn't have some of the varieties of beans listed, so I improvised with what I had -- 2 cans kidney beans, 2 cans great northern, 1 can black beans. The rest of the recipe I followed exactly. I thought there was too much molasses as it was the most prominent flavor I noticed when tasting the beans. I think if I were to make this again, I would cut back on the molasses since the recipe also calls for brown sugar, which already contains molasses. I was able to salvage this recipe by adding some onion powder, garlic powder, a little bit of salt, and a bit more Worcestershire. This made a 9 x 13 size casserole dish, which is more than enough for 2 of us for dinner, so I'm hoping that the leftovers will taste better for lunch tomorrow.
Easy to make and great hot or cold. We all loved these sweet-tangy beans. Be sure to cut or crumble the bacon into small bite size pieces. Goes great with sliders.
The best baked bean recipe I've ever made. I make it for any barbecue or summer potluck.
I will definitely make these again, I loved all the different beans.
I loved it , but I did add green bell pepper, fresh garlic, pineapple, and allspice.
I? substituted some different beans in my house for the beans it called for and it was really good! It definitely went over well with my family!
I followed the recipe exactly but found the beans bland.
Everyone loved it and they are requesting I do it again. I also made a vegan friendly version based on this recipe and it was also amazing!
Very festive and tasty. Too sweet even without the brown sugar. Next time I'll cut molasses to 1/3 cup and Inadded salt and a tablespoon of vinegar.
Best baked beans ever. Family and friends loved them. Don't change a thing, the recipe is perfect as is.
Made this for the 4th of July BBQ and it was a hit! Everyone loved the flavor. I used my slow cooker with the recipe as written. Cooked it on low for 6 hours and then on high for one hour uncovered.
The best baked beans I ever had. I added one diced green pepper.
I thought it was a little too sweet but everyone else loved it!
Everyone loved it. Personally, in future, I'll leave out the Garbanzo (chick peas). This recipe would be awesome, just simply using 4-5 cans of Bush baked beans w/the other ingredients.

Awesome beans! Everyone loves them. Great for a potluck or cookout. I used black, navy, pinto and baked beans. I don't like kidney beans, so left them out. I've made this recipe twice this summer. Love it.
Great recipe! Subbed black beans for garbanzo and added a touch of maple syrup. Cooked in the crock pot- delicious!
Loved this bean dish and would make it again!
Took this to a cookout, where everyone LOVED it! Definitely, this recipe is a keeper!
I do my Mom's mother's day party every year....100 or so people. This year was a western theme so thought baked beans were in order. I followed others advise and these were WONDERFUL!!!!

So this was good as is but I really needed a base recipe for trying to copy a BBQ joints recipe. Things I changed: used a quart each of home canned great northern and pinto beans, added 2 teaspoons curry powder. I'm pretty close to the original but very satisfied with what I turned out with.

The recipe, prepared exactly as directed, was a huge hit at my gathering. Other than frying bacon (which I hate), this was super-easy to assemble and cook. For my own personal taste, I would change the types of beans to ones that are less chewy and substantial as I love smushy baked beans; most are not like me so this is a great idea and I have lots of 5-star votes to prove it!
Great classic barbecue recipe. I always find this type of recipe too sweet, so I cut the brown sugar to 2 Tbsp and kept everything else as described . Excellent.

I made this recipe to the T. I don't like the crunchy beans in this, so next time I will go with all soft type beans. Other than that, we really liked the flavor. I will certainly be tweaking this to our likes.

I made this recipe to the T. I don't like the crunchy beans in this, so next time I will go with all soft type beans. Other than that, we really liked the flavor. I will certainly be tweaking this to our likes.
I made this Friday and I didn't have all those different beans so I used a can of Randall's mixed beans along with the Sriracha baked beans, it was amazing!

So good. Have made these three times in as many weeks. Made ALMOST as written except made vegetarian by using some veggie bacon and veggie chorizo. Left out molasses because that is a food I have never eaten in my life so didn't want to chance a new taste. Also left out the garbanzo beans since it just seemed like that was a weird kind of bean to go in there. Soooooooooooooooooooooo delicious.

These beans were so great we had them for breakfast :o) The trick to using different types of beans (I used dried black and pinto beans) is that the ENTIRE RECIPE is not done until the bean needing the longest-cooking time is tender. And use a crock pot. Period. I cooked these for 24-30 hours (longer time because they were dried to start) and they came out fabulous! Other changes for healthier (read: less sugar) and tangier/more savory beans: substitute stevia in the raw (20 packets) for the white sugar, chop a huge Costco yellow onion vs 1 cup, 3 heaping tsp. Grandma's molasses, 6 oz tomato paste, 3/4 c. tomato sauce, 3 heaping Tbsp. minced garlic vs 1 clove. *The mustard makes this dish* - use Dijon (with white wine) - 4 heaping Tbsp. to start and then to taste. Omit white sugar and brown sugar, as well as the ketchup. Kept the Worcester sauce and black pepper the same. Meat is optional - I didn't use bacon or turkey because I didn't' have any in the fridge at the time - they were still super good and I'll DEFINITELY be making them again!

These were just okay for me but the people at the party where I shared them loved them because they like molasses in their baked beans and I do not. Personally, I didn't like that much molasses so I will make them will less next time and I will probably cook the beans a lot longer because they were still hard and I like a softer beans when baked.
I have made these several times, and they are always a big hit!
Super good!
Followed the seasonings exactly, but didn't have any garbanzo beans so I just used another can of pinto beans. It was great!
Sweet and tangy baked beans. My kids and hubby loved it. Will make it again.

My go to recipe from now on. Didn't have time to soak beans so used canned, well rinsed and drained: Kidney, Black, Chick pea and 2 cans Mixed. I trimmed the fat off of a package of low sodium bacon and sautéed it with onion and garlic, then added approx 3 c diced low sodium ham. For the sauce, I started in a 2 cup measure so I could adjust accordingly: 3 T each ketchup, molasses and BBQ sauce. 2 T maple syrup, yellow mustard, 1 T Worcester, 1 tsp each Smokey Paprika (excellent) and cayenne. (No brown sugar needed.) I cooked it on the stove top and kept adding sauce and lost track of the proportions. It tasted soo good, even before baking in the oven. Due to time I had to finish in the oven, 275*, 2 hrs, but hope to cook this in the crock pot next time. Thank you for a great motivation!
